div.l: Thanne wille I ben by nethe by my croun
And se how that the mele falles a doun
In to the trough that schal be my disporte
For Iohn in faith I may be of youre sorte
I am as yuyll myller as ar ye
This Miller smylid of hir nycete
And though all this nys don but for wile
Thei wene that no man may hem by gile
But by my thrifte yit schal I blere hir yeie
For all the sleight of hir philosophie
The mo queynte crekis that they make
The more wole I stele whanne I take
In stede of floure yit wol I yeue hem bren
The grettest clerkis buth nat wiseste men
As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
Of al hir Arte counte I nought a tare
¶ Out at the dore he gothe ful preuely
Whenne that he sawe his tyme softely
He lokith vp and doune til he hath founde
The clerkis hors ther as it stode I bounde
By hynde the mylle vndir a leuesell
And to the hors he hym goth faire and welle
He strepith of the bridill right a non
And whanne the hors was laws he gynnyth to gon
Toward the fenne there wilde maris renne
And forth with we he thorw thikke and thourgh thynne
This Mileward cometh a gayn no worde he saide
Butt doth his note and with the Clerkis pleide
Til that hir corne was faire and wel I grounde
And whenne hure mele is sakkid and I bounde
This Iohn goth oute and fidith his hors a way
And ganne to crie harow and weleaway
Oure hors Aley Aley is lost Aleyn for goddis bones
Step on thi fete com oute man al attones
Allas our wardeyn hath his palfrey lorne
This Aleyn al for gate bothe mele and corne
Al was oute of his mynde his housbondrie
What whilke way is he gon gan he to crie
The wif com lepyng inward with a renne
Sche saide allas your hors goth to the fenne
With wilde Maris as fast as he may goo
Vnthanke com on his hand that bound hym soo
